file_name: VOLF BUDG 2025_0206BUD Draft Amending Budget No 2-2025 [Negrescu]_EN
author: original text
vl_title_en: Draft amending budget No 2/2025: update of revenue (own resources) and adjustments to expenditure

file_name: VOLF BUDG 2025_0206BUD Draft Amending Budget No 2-2025 [Negrescu]_EN
author: ESN
remarks: “Regrets the lack of proposals from the Commission to reduce Union expenditure, particularly in the operating costs of administrations; considers it urgent to adopt an austerity plan that will enable the Union to reduce its debt without increasing the tax burden on taxpayers”
vl_title_en: Draft amending budget No 2/2025: update of revenue (own resources) and adjustments to expenditure

file_name: VOLF BUDG 2025_0206BUD Draft Amending Budget No 2-2025 [Negrescu]_EN
author: ESN
remarks: “Considers that the adoption of “own resources” for the European Union, which smacks of federalist ulterior motives, would encourage the pursuit of irresponsible, reckless spending;”
vl_title_en: Draft amending budget No 2/2025: update of revenue (own resources) and adjustments to expenditure

file_name: VOLF BUDG 2025_0206BUD Draft Amending Budget No 2-2025 [Negrescu]_EN
author: ESN
remarks: “Considers it essential to maintain the principle that windfall gains and unspent amounts are returned to Member States at the end of the financial year;”
vl_title_en: Draft amending budget No 2/2025: update of revenue (own resources) and adjustments to expenditure

file_name: VOLF BUDG 2025_0206BUD Draft Amending Budget No 2-2025 [Negrescu]_EN
author: original text
remarks: “Underlines that lessons from recent crises – pandemic, energy shocks, and the war in Ukraine – require a serious reflection about flexibility in the next MFF; reiterates its position that the future Flexibility Instrument should be fed through a number of additional sources of financing, including the annual surplus from the previous year, fines and reflows; takes note of the relevant provisions in the proposed MFF Regulation, where the Commission proposes to add certain amounts to the Flexibility Instrument, in line with Parliament’s long-standing demands; recalls, however, that flexibility should not come at the expense of transparency;”
vl_title_en: Draft amending budget No 2/2025: update of revenue (own resources) and adjustments to expenditure

file_name: VOLF BUDG 2025_0206BUD Draft Amending Budget No 2-2025 [Negrescu]_EN
author: PfE
vl_title_en: Draft amending budget No 2/2025: update of revenue (own resources) and adjustments to expenditure

file_name: VOLF BUDG 2025_0206BUD Draft Amending Budget No 2-2025 [Negrescu]_EN
author: Original text
vl_title_en: Draft amending budget No 2/2025: update of revenue (own resources) and adjustments to expenditure

file_name: VOLF BUDG 2025_0206BUD Draft Amending Budget No 2-2025 [Negrescu]_EN
remarks: “Further considers questionable the compensation of the additional needs for the centralised customs system in Heading 1 and CBAM in Heading 3 by a commensurate decrease of allocations under the Customs Control Equipment Instrument in Heading 4”
vl_title_en: Draft amending budget No 2/2025: update of revenue (own resources) and adjustments to expenditure

file_name: VOLF BUDG 2025_0206BUD Draft Amending Budget No 2-2025 [Negrescu]_EN
remarks: “Regrets that the current budgetary situation has led the Commission to redeploy significant funds across Headings and recalls its long-standing position that new policy priorities, tasks or needs should be accompanied by fresh money; stresses strongly that recurrent redeployments are not a viable way to finance the Union’s priorities as they damage investments and jeopardise the delivery of agreed policy objectives;”
vl_title_en: Draft amending budget No 2/2025: update of revenue (own resources) and adjustments to expenditure

file_name: VOLF BUDG 2025_0206BUD Draft Amending Budget No 2-2025 [Negrescu]_EN
author: PfE
vl_title_en: Draft amending budget No 2/2025: update of revenue (own resources) and adjustments to expenditure

file_name: VOLF BUDG 2025_0206BUD Draft Amending Budget No 2-2025 [Negrescu]_EN
author: PfE
remarks: “whereas Draft amending budget No 2/2025 entails a revision of the own resources forecasts in relation to customs duties, which are 1% below the May 2024 forecast, in relation to the capped VAT base, which is 2,4 % below the May 2024 forecast, in relation to non-recycled plastic packaging waste, which is down 3,5 % compared to the May 2024 forecast, and in relation to the total EU GNI base, which is 0,5 % higher than the May 2024 forecast, which demonstrates misleading and imprudent budgetary forecasts,”
vl_title_en: Draft amending budget No 2/2025: update of revenue (own resources) and adjustments to expenditure

file_name: VOLF BUDG 2025_0206BUD Draft Amending Budget No 2-2025 [Negrescu]_EN
author: PfE
remarks: “Whereas Draft amending budget No 2/2025 also updates the 2025 United Kingdom contribution pursuant to the withdrawal agreement, which stands at EUR 1,53 billion, a modest reduction of EUR 25 million compared to the estimate included in the 2025 budget, which once again demonstrates that the initial budgetary forecast was overly optimistic and therefore imprudent and misleading,”
vl_title_en: Draft amending budget No 2/2025: update of revenue (own resources) and adjustments to expenditure

endemic corruption and poor governance are the main causes of Haiti’s security and humanitarian crisis, fuelling gang violence; linkage between Haiti’s political and economic elites and gangs; allegations of corruption within Haiti’s transitional governing bodies

Covered already
(vote against to support a coalition agreement)
vl_title_en: Deliberations of the Committee on Petitions in 2024

author: The Left
vl_title_en: Deliberations of the Committee on Petitions in 2024

author: original text
remarks: Mentions petitions received on rule of law in Spain and its implications for Spanish and EU legal frameworks.
vl_title_en: Deliberations of the Committee on Petitions in 2024

author: Greens/ EFA
remarks:
mentions pesticides and toxicity testing: Environmental/health concerns are valid, but these belong to ENVI committee and legislative work, not the Petitions annual report. The report already mentions environment as a top category of petitions

(vote against to support a coalition agreement)
vl_title_en: Deliberations of the Committee on Petitions in 2024

author: Greens/ EFA
remarks:
mentions enforcement delays in infringement procedures : The report already stresses better enforcement, transparency and follow-up of petitions. Adding specific cases (ILVA steel plant) duplicates content and risks targeting individual Member States. 
Covered already
(vote against to support a coalition agreement)
vl_title_en: Deliberations of the Committee on Petitions in 2024

author: Greens/ EFA
remarks:
mentions fossil fuels lobbying and advertising bans: The report already highlights citizens’ environmental and climate concerns. Calls for bans and criminalisation go far beyond the remit of the Petitions Committee. 
Covered in broader terms already
(vote against to support a coalition agreement)
vl_title_en: Deliberations of the Committee on Petitions in 2024

author: Greens/ EFA
remarks:
Tabled by a Spanish MEP from Galicia, mentions alleged double standards in the treatment of a Galician petition.  Mentions alleged double standards/Galicia case: The report already commits to fair, transparent and equal treatment of petitions. Naming specific petitions is confrontational and politicises the Committee. 
Covered already
(vote against to support a coalition agreement)
vl_title_en: Deliberations of the Committee on Petitions in 2024

author: Greens/ EFA
remarks:
mentions agenda right for groups pluralism: The report already calls for pluralism and accessibility of the petitions process. Guaranteeing slots for groups risks politicising the agenda. 
Covered by existing transparency provisions

(vote against to support a coalition agreement)
vl_title_en: Deliberations of the Committee on Petitions in 2024

author: The Left
remarks:
Tabled by Greek MEP, mentions the train accident in Tempi, Greece. PETI has agreed to do a fact finding visit to Greece on this issue in the second half of 2026 so this subject will focused on in detail then.  

(vote against to support a coalition agreement)
vl_title_en: Deliberations of the Committee on Petitions in 2024

author: original text
vl_title_en: Deliberations of the Committee on Petitions in 2024
Deliberations of the Committee on Petitions in 2024

remarks:
Split tabled by Spanish Green/EFA member, it aims to upset the delicate balance struck in the text adopted in Committee between platform Groups regarding Catalonia - 
Keep original text

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0415/2025(EPP, S&D, ECR, Renew, Greens/ EFA and The Left)
remarks: Notes with grave concern that 1300 human rights defenders, journalists and other public figures who have supported the development of democracy in Afghanistan over the last decade, are still waiting in Pakistan to be admitted to European Member States after having been  provided with documentation that allowed for temporary status in Pakistan, while their asylum request is processed; expresses deep concern about the ongoing deportations that are now also targeting these groups;

subject_of_the_amendment: vote: decision to enter interinstitutional negotiations
remarks:
Voting in favour means endorsing the JURI “VdL” compromise and proceeding with trilogue negotiations
Voting against means calling for opening a new deadline for amendments at plenary level in Novembre
The JURI mandate was challenged by PfE, ECR, Greens, The Left and ESN

file_name: VOLF CONT 20242021DEC Discharge 2023_2nd report_EU Council & Council [Brudzinski]_EN
heading: Motion for a resolution
remarks: Welcomes the decision to adopt conclusions supported by 26 member states on the EU’s continued and unwavering support for Ukraine’s independence, sovereignty, and territorial integrity, as set out in European Council document EUCO 16/25 adopted on 26 June 2025; regrets that such a course was necessary due to persistent vetoes; calls for the development of alternative mechanisms to bypass vetoes in urgent matters, pending treaty changes to improve decision-making efficiency and unity within the European Council; underlines that the EU budget 2023 has already mobilised substantial resources to support Ukraine, and stresses the importance of ensuring that future budgetary decisions reflect this strategic commitment.
vl_title_en: Discharge 2023: EU general budget – European Council and Council

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
author: original text
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks: Acknowledges that the aim of unanimity is to ensure that the legitimate concerns of all Member States are addressed; believes, however, that an enlarged EU will require more sophisticated coordination in addressing the challenges of the current enlargement process;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks: believes, however, that an enlarged EU will require more sophisticated coordination in addressing the challenges of the current enlargement process;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks: underlines the importance of addressing the difficulties caused by unanimity in the Council, including the use of unanimity for intermediate steps in the enlargement process, which could slow down the EU accession of new members owing to bilateral issues;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks: recalls that Article 49 TEU enables a move to QMV without requiring Treaty changes;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks: takes note of the cumbersome and outdated structure and governance of the EU budget and the possible redistribution in the allocation of agricultural and cohesion funds; recalls that EU enlargement is an opportunity to recalibrate key EU policies in this respect;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks: supports initiatives aimed at making the decision-making process more effective, which is key to enhancing the EU’s competitiveness;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

remarks: composition of the Commission must take enlargement into account
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
author: original text
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks: Recognises the need for reflection on the revision of the Council’s functioning and decision-making process in view of enlargement; notes that qualified majority must be redefined to improve the balance between larger and smaller countries and to retain higher thresholds for the most important and politically delicate decisions; recalls, in this regard, its resolution of 22 November 2023 on proposals of the European Parliament for the amendment of the Treaties, in particular on voting majorities in the Council;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks: calls for the utmost transparency and integrity of the Council’s decision-making process in the context of enlargement;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
author: original text
remarks: Proposes strengthening and reforming the procedure in Article 7 TEU by ending unanimity in European Council decisions, by introducing a clear time frame and by making the Court of Justice of the European Union the arbiter of violations;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
author: original text
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

remarks: Split request withdrawn, will not be put to the vote

remarks:

vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks: Considers that the above objectives of the institutional pre-enlargement reforms can be implemented by various means, including by activating the flexibilities offered by the current Treaties
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks: through one or more targeted Treaty amendments
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
author: MEPs
remarks: AM by Patriot Members
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
author: original text
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks: Recalls that a number of flexibility instruments, such as passerelle clauses, enhanced cooperation, constructive abstentions, PESCO and opt-out mechanisms, are already possible under the current EU legal framework, as evidenced by the experiences of the Schengen area, one of the greatest achievements of the EU, and the single currency; recalls that phasing-in solutions, temporary derogations and transition periods can be negotiated for certain policy fields in the context of accession procedures;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks:
The words:
such as passerelle clauses, enhanced cooperation, constructive abstentions, PESCO and opt-out mechanisms
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
author: original text
remarks: Insists, that, in order to effectively reform the EU’s institutional framework in view of European unification, some targeted key Treaty changes are indispensable; recalls, in this respect, its suggestions from its resolution of 22 November 2023 on proposals of the European Parliament for the amendment of the Treaties, in particular with regard to the reform of decision-making in the EU, increasing the use of QMV and the ordinary legislative procedure, the composition of the Commission, and further empowering the European Parliament; reminds the European Council of its Treaty obligation to follow-up on Parliament’s activation of the ordinary Treaty reform procedure under Article 48 TEU;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
author: original text
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
author: original text
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
author: original text
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
author: original text
remarks: whereas enlargement is a historic commitment, a key EU foreign policy tool, a strategic geopolitical priority and one of the EU’s most successful policies, representing an investment in the future of the European continent;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
author: original text
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks: whereas the EU’s institutional framework, [and in particular its decision-making processes], need to be strengthened and improved for the current European Union of 27 Member States;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks:
The words;
and in particular its decision-making processes
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks: whereas preparing for enlargement requires internal reforms within the EU and whereas the enlargement process should be pursued in parallel with the institutional [and decision-making reforms] necessary to safeguard the EU’s integration capacity;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks:
The words;
and decision-making reforms
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks: whereas the prospect of future enlargements makes the reform of the EU institutions, policies [and decision-making procedures] more necessary and urgent than ever;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks:
The words:
and decision-making procedures
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
author: original text
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks: whereas passerelle clauses could be used immediately to switch from the requirement for unanimity to qualified majority voting (QMV) in specific policy areas;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
remarks: whereas the TEU establishes that the ultimate objective of the progressive framing of a common EU defence policy is the establishment of a common defence by unanimous decision of the European Council, which must be compatible with NATO;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

file_name: VOLF AFCO 2025_2041INI Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations [Gozi]_EN
author: original text
remarks: whereas, due to the limited flexibility of the Treaties, a more in-depth reform by means of targeted Treaty changes should be envisaged; whereas Parliament has activated the Treaty revision procedure and has submitted proposals for the amendment of the Treaties to the Council in accordance with Article 48(2) TEU;
vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

vl_title_en: Institutional consequences of the EU enlargement negotiations

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
author: ESN
remarks: Persecution of Christians: claims widespread persecution of Christians in sub-Saharan Africa and calls for EU aid and cooperation to be made conditional on improving their situation.
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
author: PfE
remarks: EU aid misuse and corruption: calls for an audit of EU development funding, criticising so-called “ideological projects” and citing examples from the European Court of Auditors. Stresses that aid must go to recipients and not feed corruption.
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

author: original text
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
author: EPP
remarks: Youth exchanges: simplifies the reference to student mobility by emphasising participation of European students in exchanges with African universities, and by removing references to specific programmes such as Erasmus+ or Intra-Africa schemes.
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
author: original text
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
remarks: These words: “Stresses that African young people must be at the heart of a renewed EU-Africa partnership; stresses that the EU-AU partnership serves as an opportunity for African governments to provide possibilities, including job creation, for their citizens, and that the EU can assist and support such African-driven efforts”
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
remarks: These words: “underlines that bringing young people from both continents closer together, through greater mutual understanding and stronger bonds, is essential for a lasting and equal partnership”
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
remarks: These words: “calls for the strengthening of student and research exchange programmes”
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
remarks: These words: “such as Erasmus+”
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
remarks: These words: “the creation of a political EU-Africa youth exchange programme”
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
remarks: These words: “and the Intra-Africa Academic Mobility Scheme to reach more EU and African students and researchers”
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
remarks: These words: “calls, moreover, for increased support for African universities, vocational institutes and youth-led initiatives to strengthen skills, innovation”
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
remarks: These words: “and exchange”
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
author: EPP
remarks:
adoption 10 = 6 falls
Migration cooperation and counterterrorism: substantially rewrites the paragraph to centre EU-Africa cooperation on migration control, return/readmission, and security
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
author: ECR
remarks: Migration conditionality: removes positive language on legal pathways, mutual benefits, and human rights, and instead calls for an EU-Africa cooperation policy based on conditionality criteria in migration matters; shifts the focus from partnership to migration control and reciprocal obligations.
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
author: original text
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
remarks: These words: “Recognises that migration is a shared reality”
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
remarks: These words: “and a potential source of opportunity for both continents”
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
remarks: These words: “when managed in a safe, legal and mutually beneficial way”
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
remarks: These words: “stresses that both continents must jointly tackle the root causes of irregular migration, strengthen border management and combat human trafficking and smuggling networks; underlines that effective readmission and return policies are essential for cooperation on mobility and visa facilitation”
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
remarks: These words: “calls for cooperation on well-regulated legal migration methods”
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
remarks: These words: ”emphasises that all migration must be safe, orderly and organised in full respect of human rights and international law”
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
author: ESN
remarks: Illegal migration: criticises the EU’s asylum system and urges the Commission and Council to prioritise the fight against illegal migration at the upcoming Angola Summit.
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
author: PfE
remarks: Migration conditionality: demands that EU development cooperation be conditional on good governance and cooperation on migration and border control; urges binding migration partnerships and explicitly rejects the creation of new legal migration pathways.
vl_title_en: Renewing the EU-Africa Partnership: building common priorities ahead of the Angola Summit

heading: Joint motion for a resolution RC10-0471/2025(EPP, S&D, Renew and Greens/ EFA)
author: EPP
remarks: Migration partnerships and security: reframes migration as a major challenge rather than a shared opportunity. Calls for long-term EU-Africa partnerships centred on responsibility, border management, counter-terrorism, and prevention of irregular migration, introducing a stronger focus on control and measurable commitments.
